history.content:
Former 61B staff member here. The following is a "transition matrix" showing what percent of people who received grade X in 61A received grade Y in 61B:

For instance, of people who received an A in 61A, 61.31% received an A in 61B.

This is based on self-reported 61A grades and actual 61B grades for the Spring 2016 offering of 61B. Every row has $$n\geq50$$ sample points. Students who dropped 61B are not included.

[Posted with permission of Prof. Hug.]

----

Honestly it's very similar to doing well in 61A. Like in 61A, since basically everyone gets 100% on the labs, homeworks, and projects (since there are accessible autograders), your grade is almost entirely determined by how you do on the 2 midterms and final, so study hard (esp. do lots of practice tests) for those.

The big difference with 61A is that the amount of effort that goes into homeworks and projects seriously increases, so actually start them early. I think I averaged 5-10 hours a homework and 20-40 hours a project. Also, I would avoid using lab drops and homework drops, because they are often where you learn the content the best.

I wouldn't really recommend reading a textbook. Hug's lectures and corresponding lecture slides are really good, esp. for the second half--the data structures half--of the course.

---------------------------

---------------------------

I am taking CS 61B next semester, and I am wondering how hard it is to get A/A- in the class? I got A in CS 61A with previous programming experience and the effort of going to all lecture/discussion/lab + OH. I understand CS 61A is different from CS 61B, but I want to know if with the similar effort, I could get a good grade in CS 61B (asking because of GPA cutoff). Thank you!
history.subject: CS 61B Grade?
